content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I had fun doing geometry =)

Nice and easy-to-understand problem. Clear directions and fun to solve. Would recommend ++

EDIT : would accept it if i was moderator. Careful for C++ though, you'll need to define a small error for right angle triangle to make it work. GL

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem is clear enough, with some useful geometry practice. I had some problems with the string formatting, which are now resolved.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Mathematical parts (length,angles) is usefull for other puzzles and contests, and the other parts can be easily found on the web.
Nice trigo puzzle...!!

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Quadrilaterals was already borderline too easy.
Triangles goes way past that. Currently too tedious (IMHO) for a clash.

We already have this puzzle:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/183a96dd151d7e7b1c563816338ee2f6baa

I don't see the point in accepting the current proposal.

Edited the text for a clearer presentation.

Changed difficulty to Easy.

There is no obtuse triangle in the "Everything" test case and validator. Maybe add one obtuse triangle in each of them?

"You won’t have degenerate triangles."  
First test case A,B and C are co-linear.
Maybe can say if flat output acute? dunno

You should add a range on coordinates
and add some tests that trigger integer overflow (because there certainly are some multiplications / additions in the solution code)
:)
How are the coordinates (-1,-1), (1,1), (4,4) not a straight line? Thank you.
No equilateral triangles or would it be covered with one of the other definitions? Thanks.

If you add the definition of "isosceles", it may be good to add the definition of "scalene". I knew the meaning of the first word, but not of the second.
It may be useful for people that didn't learn mathematics in English :-)
Done.
Equilateral triangles need the exact value of sqrt(3).
Darn.
Thanks.
Done.

It’s not the same puzzle.
Quadrilaterals is easy this one is a bit less easy (and it needs trigonometry, not Quadrilaterals).

I can't argue against the similarity as mentioned by Stilgart in his comment, but it doesn't seem that easy for a newbie - there are questions raised on this puzzle from time to time (the recent top questioned ones seem to be Power of Thor, ISBN Check Digits, The River I & II, What's so complex about Mandelbrot? and the Nature of Quadrilaterals).

In Python:
    >>> ord("°")
    176
Why don’t you use the symbol itself?

It could be that I missed the full stop at the end of the line. But has something changed in the tester or examples? I'm sure yesterday it was saying something like:
Failure
Found: ABC is a scalene and an obtuse in A (176\-62\-80) triangle
Expected: ABC is a scalene and an obtuse in A (176°) triangle.
Nothing changed until a long time.
And somehow Nature of Quadrilaterals are one of the Easy puzzles which have a solving rate of <60%. I don't expect it to be that low as well.

If I read my old solution to quads, and more importantly the comment to go along with it, my opinion of it is quite low, but the solution to it is still easy. So I'd personally  interpret questions to ir as "badly set" more than as "hard".

My mantra in the puzzles section is 
"make puzzles fun and challenging, not boring and tedious."

At any rate, you're welcome to have a differing opinion to mine. Diversity is the spice of life!
Totally agree on your comment on diversity :)

Both can be solved by first computing all the distances between pairs of points and then use the appropriate test on them.

One way to improve this puzzle is to also ask for an angle, so that people will have to rely on angles and not on distances.
Yep but which angle?
One can ask for either all three of them in increasing order, or only the obtuse one when the triangle is obtuse.

OK for the last proposition.
Done.

I suggest the output be simplified as "obtuse in [[vertex]] {{(}}[[angle]]{{°)}}", e.g.

DEF is an isosceles in D and an obtuse in D (120°) triangle.
Done.
I've re-checked the test cases and validators, revised the statement regarding obtuse triangles, and re-approved the puzzle.
